title: Everyone always misses the point of reworks.
body:
It's not about making them stronger or weaker. It's about changing unhealthy play styles or generic kits that do everything. On a grander scale, for class reworks, it's about changing a large pool of champions that suffer from abusive interactions with itemization, weak synergies in need of updating, infrequent niches and various other reasons to name a few examples. 

When these reworks happen, the initial goal isn't to gut a champion, to make them stronger or anything like that. It's to make it so Riot can make broad changes without fear of certain champions abusing said changes. People talk about all the class reworks being a failure and maybe some of them have yielded some less than desirable results for certain champions. In those cases, that's probably a good thing because it just shows those champions required isolated attention. In the larger scheme though, those changes produced better itemization, healthier gameplay and stronger diversity.

People will likely go nuts and point to "failures" such as Malz, Morde, etc. To which I'll point to you Darius, Vlad (who I initially hated but once I played and got familiar with playing against I love), Swain, etc. More importantly, black cleaver became a staple item across the board in the juggernaut patch. AP itemization has greatly diversified since the mage update as opposed to stack as much AP/CDR as you can, assassins got their own items. ADCs overall got more diverse and less generic right clickers. In the big picture, these updates made the game better. Yes, some cases sucked and some will need to be looked at but riot isn't perfect - neither are you. But for those that are "weak" from these reworks, guess what riot can finally do now? *Buff them without fear of breaking them.* 

Tanks might be good, they might be bad - I don't know. It's going to take a few patches before we know for sure. But by the end of the season, I can promise you that overall, once Riot figured it out, tanks will definitely be healthier and better overall.  And that's the ultimate goal of class updates and in my mind, they've been extremely successful.

That's fine. And while people will complain until the cows come home about the power levels of the rework, that's not what's actually bothering them. Nobody's that concerned about the power level; it's that reworked champions will often _feel like shit to play_.

Take new Sej: everyone agrees that she's strong, even too strong. But she still feels shitty to play, because her kit is clunky, counter-intuitive, and has massive power budgeted into the least satisfying abilities.

Her q is...basically the same, though a bunch of damage was removed. Her w, most people agree, is far more satisfying to use and has a lot more play around it - but then the damage is shit. Her e feels like she gets basically no agency in whether or not she gets to use it, and, by extension, her passive bonus damage feels the same.

A ton of her damage is locked up in her e and passive, and that feels like shit.

Let's go to another example, Zac: His new ulti actually is more interesting than his older one, but it's also a hell of a lot less reliable and has a lot of frustrating tied into getting it off. Same goes for his q, it's a fun quirky mechanic, but they removed the reliability from it and it feels clunky as hell to use.

That's not something you want to happen to your main's kit.

And lastly, Malzahar, the rework everyone hates: People don't really care about his winrate. People also don't want him to be able to get a free kill whenever his ulti is up, as fun as it was. People just want his power budget to be shifted from his w and passive back into his qer. Like, I used to play a ton of Malz, and he just isn't _satisfying_ anymore.

I understand your point but I addressed this in the OP. If it turns out that a champions update in a class update isn't good or feels less satisfying, then it's clear that champion need individual attention. It sucks for your main, I don't dispute this but this is always a chance you take when you religiously main a champion. Nobody likes it or likes to talk about it but in the long run, especially with older champions, it's inevitable that they'll experience some sort of rework along the way.

>I understand your point but I addressed this in the OP. If it turns out that a champions update in a class update isn't good or feels less satisfying, then it's clear that champion need individual attention.

That's nowhere near fucking good enough.

Riot needs to learn to admit when they fuck up and be willing to revert the champs to the last point where they weren't complete garbage rather than just leaving them in a perpetually shit state for years.

> than just leaving them in a perpetually shit state for years.

If we're using only Class Reworks as an example for that, I don't think that's happened ever. (Other than Morde, but he has issues on issues only solvable through VGU, BUT they did put a good deal of effort in trying to make him viable in a Solo lane (ask Malicious))

Kog'maw? 

As far back as I can remember Riot has only ever reverted one set of changes that made it live, those were the Kog'maw changes and Kog was a part of a champ update. This revert was easily the best thing they could do for him, I just wish they'd be willing to do the same for others.

Kog'Maw got constant changes though, it's not like they left him alone, as shit, and then reverted it X months later. They tried and tried making his new thing work for a long time, and than they admitted defeat. So, if we're using Kog as an example, you'd have to wait for many months worth of changes to go by before they would consider reverting.

They wasted resources trying to fix a bad rework. Typical example of a sunk costs fallacy. It's not worth wasting more resources than you already have trying to fix something you broke. It's better just to restart it to the last point where it worked.

To be honest though I've never seen a company fall harder for the sunk costs fallacy than Riot does. They're unwilling to let even their worst work "go to waste". This is why we had DQ forced down out throats for a whole year last year and Riot still refuses to admit it's a shit queue despite it being a dead queue with 15 minute waits and super uneven matches because no-one wants it.

See, here's the difference between you and Riot. *You* see the Rework as a failure. *They* see the rework as needing some work. That's not a bad thing, lots of projects are hardly "Boom, Fixed". You also need to define what your definition of "Last worked" and what their's is. They rework for many a reason, both parties could be looking at different reasons. 

Now, I don't disagree with you here, but I don't agree with you either, simply because you are looking through a very *Customer Point of View*. You see a product you don't like, so you don't want it. Easy, simple, no effort involved. All the power to you. 

Riot is a Business, and Business's have a very different view point on everything, and this is worth mentioning. Let's use McDonalds and Minimum wage as an example. From a customer view point, asking for a dollar more minimum wage seems fairly insignificant, very small. But it's not for McDonalds, because they look at the very long term situations. 

They look at 5 to 10 to 20 year plans in how they can make money. While a one dollar raise may seem insignificant now, in ten years, that could be a very large amount of money lost. It also works the same way with new products, or new machinery. They may take a hit for this year in revenue, but buying new machines could increase their revenue by 20% over the following years, so it's worth the initial hit to make more. 

So this is where I disagree with people when they say "DQ should've been reverted ASAP", because that's a very customer based view. A year to **try** and fix a new system, even if it meant that they may take a hit the current year, is well worth the effort if it is able to achieve a better system that will be better throughout the years (be it Revenue or Ranked matchmaking, your choice).  

Now, it didn't work as we see now, but for a business a year is hardly anything when it comes to trying something new, if it has potential for making something better. It didn't, and that's not the point here, but scrapping without any attempt at fixing is a faulty way to test out new things.

>Riot is a Business, and Business's have a very different view point on everything, and this is worth mentioning. Let's use McDonalds and Minimum wage as an example. From a customer view point, asking for a dollar more minimum wage seems fairly insignificant, very small. But it's not for McDonalds, because they look at the very long term situations.

That's not really an equivalent example TBH. It's never in McDonald's interest to raise wages unless forced, it's very easy to imagine scenarios where both reverting and not reverting reworks. They also wouldn't really be changing the product at all in the same way Riot has.

Also the idea that McDonalds would pass the expense of a raised minimum wage onto consumers is already shaky in the first place. In Australia McDonalds is cheaper than in America and we have an 18.70 AUD min wage. McDonalds just has to operate at a lower margin in Australia than in the USA, if they tried to raise their prices they'd lose marketshare to other fast food restaurants they can't lower their wages from what they are now. But that's fairly tangential anyway.

I'd say a fairer example here would be "new Coke". Coke at one point tried to change their formula and it was an utter dumpster fire. Over a couple of months they lost almost all of their marketshare to Pepsi. They were quick to bring back old Coke when public perception turned against them damned be the costs they sunk into developing new Coke.

It wasn't meant to be a literal example, it was meant to show the long term thinking of Companies. 

And no, I wouldn't compare either New Coke to this either. "New Coke" was meant to compete with Pepsi, a much sweeter drink, and you're right, they failed and it got switched back. **However**, you can't hoist the same time span on this to be considered an absolute failure and then reverted, as you can with League. 

For one, Coca Cola had a *much faster* reaction to their product going down. If you were to take a Survey of it, the type of people who drink Cola drink Coke because it's Coke. They don't want Pepsi, they want Coke, it's just their thang. Coke and Pepsi are fairly different enough they don't overlap in customer base ~~unless you're that guy~~. So if people who normally drink Coke aren't drinking Coke, that's a big problem. 

Dynamic Que was no where near the type of immediate reaction, because League of Legends is still a fairly big and unique enough product that they could afford a temporary hit. The Food industry is much more competitive, especially back then, where any lead was a big one. 

That, and not to mention the true fact, that there was a fairly decent sized amount of people who enjoyed Dynamic Que. Unlike food, and we're using a singular product size, you can have a varied amount of people who enjoy different aspects of a game. Food is pretty "Get what you buy", which very limited room for varied opinion. Riot wants to try to appeal to the largest amount of people, not singular groups. 

So unlike Coke, who had had a HUGE immediate reaction with the Market, which was what prompted the revert, League did not have that. It's because they did not have that, that they decided to go the Year long trial route, and take the small hit in the hopes that they could make a better system. There is a huge difference between the two.

>That, and not to mention the true fact, that there was a fairly decent sized amount of people who enjoyed Dynamic Que.

No, there weren't. Riot wanted you to think there were and they tried to tell you there were but there simply weren't that many people who actually liked DQ. You can test this as well, considering DQ essentially still exists in the game. Go and queue up for a Flex Queue game, watch how long it takes, when you get a game look at well match making performs. Both of these will be abysmal. There just aren't that many people who want Flex Queue compared to Normals and Solo Queue.

Riot bought heavily into the sunk costs fallacy with DQ. They were hurting themselves and they knew it. They went full damage control mode for about 6 months, [let's not forget that this happened](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xwPa1SGLGv0). 

The point of sunk costs as a fallacy is that it's attractive to look at your work and say "it can be fixed with X/Y/Z" then after attempting that and failing to move the goalposts and try again. Losing all of your work isn't meant to look like attractive option even when it's the correct one. 

The difference between Riot and Coke is that Coke accepted that their sunk costs were lost, they took the path that offered the least future damage and didn't sink anymore resources trying to fix the unfixable. Riot bought into the sunk costs fallacy hook-line-and-sinker. They continued to pour resources into their failing queue and continued trying to push it even though they knew it was widely despised.
